Week 6 Discussion Notes

Table of Contents

  • Connectedness

    • Path-Connectedness
    • Connectedness and Continuity

Connectedness

Definition

Let (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) be a metric space. We say that XXX is disconnected if there exist two disjoint, non-empty, open sets U,V⊆XU, V \subseteq XU,V⊆X such that X=U∪VX = U \cup VX=U∪V.

If XXX is not disconnected, then we say that XXX is connected.
Example 1.

  • Any interval in R\RR is connected (with respect to the restricted absolute value metric).

  • Q⊆R\Q \subseteq \RQ⊆R is disconnected (with respect to the restricted absolute value metric).
Example 2.
(warmup to 2.4.6)

Let (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) be a metric space and assume A,BA, BA,B are connected sets in XXX such that A∩B=∅A \cap B = \emptysetA∩B=∅. Show that A∪BA \cup BA∪B is connected.
Solution.

Assume that A∪B=U∪VA \cup B = U \cup VA∪B=U∪V, where U,VU, VU,V are disjoint, non-empty, open sets in A∪BA \cup BA∪B. By the properties of sub-metric spaces, there exist open sets UX,VX⊆XU_X, V_X \subseteq XUX​,VX​⊆X in XXX such that U=(A∪B)∩UXU = \p{A \cup B} \cap U_XU=(A∪B)∩UX​ and V=(A∪B)∩VXV = \p{A \cup B} \cap V_XV=(A∪B)∩VX​.

Claim: A⊆UA \subseteq UA⊆U or A⊆VA \subseteq VA⊆V.

Suppose otherwise, and that A∩U≠∅A \cap U \neq \emptysetA∩U=∅ and A∩V≠∅A \cap V \neq \emptysetA∩V=∅. Notice that

A∩U=A∩(A∪B)∩UX=A∩UX,A \cap U = A \cap \p{A \cup B} \cap U_X = A \cap U_X,A∩U=A∩(A∪B)∩UX​=A∩UX​,

i.e., A∩UA \cap UA∩U is open in AAA and by symmetry, A∩VA \cap VA∩V is open in AAA also. But A∪B=U∪VA \cup B = U \cup VA∪B=U∪V, so

A=A∩(A∪B)=A∩(U∪V)(since A∪B=U∪V)=(A∩U)∪(A∩V).\begin{aligned} A &= A \cap \p{A \cup B} \\ &= A \cap \p{U \cup V} && \p{\text{since }A \cup B = U \cup V} \\ &= \p{A \cap U} \cup \p{A \cap V}. \end{aligned}A​=A∩(A∪B)=A∩(U∪V)=(A∩U)∪(A∩V).​​(since A∪B=U∪V)​

But A∩UA \cap UA∩U and A∩VA \cap VA∩V are disjoint, non-empty, and open sets in AAA, which implies that AAA is disconnected, a contradiction.

Thus, A⊆UA \subseteq UA⊆U or A⊆VA \subseteq VA⊆V. Without loss of generality, we may assume that A⊆UA \subseteq UA⊆U. In the other case, we can just replace UUU with VVV in the following argument.

Because A∩B≠∅A \cap B \neq \emptysetA∩B=∅, this means that B∩U≠∅B \cap U \neq \emptysetB∩U=∅. Since BBB is connected, this means that B⊆UB \subseteq UB⊆U as well by using the same argument in the claim, which means that A∪B⊆UA \cup B \subseteq UA∪B⊆U, so V=∅V = \emptysetV=∅, a contradiction. Thus, no such UUU and VVV existed to begin with, i.e., A∪BA \cup BA∪B is connected.
Example 3.

Let (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) be a connected metric space and let f ⁣:(X,dX)→(Y,dY)\func{f}{\p{X, d_X}}{\p{Y, d_Y}}f:(X,dX​)→(Y,dY​) be a function such that the set

E={x∈X | f(x)=y}E = \set{ x \in X \st f\p{x} = y}E={x∈X∣f(x)=y}

is non-empty, open, and closed. Show that fff is constant.
Solution.

Assume otherwise, and that fff is not constant. Then Ec≠∅E^\comp \neq \emptysetEc=∅: since E≠∅E \neq \emptysetE=∅, there exists x∈Xx \in Xx∈X such that f(x)=yf\p{x} = yf(x)=y, but fff is not constant, so there exists x′∈Xx' \in Xx′∈X such that f(x′)≠yf\p{x'} \neq yf(x′)=y, i.e., x′∈Ecx' \in E^\compx′∈Ec.

Since EEE was closed, we know that EcE^\compEc is open, and by definition,

X=E∪Ec.X = E \cup E^\comp.X=E∪Ec.

But E,EcE, E^\compE,Ec are disjoint (by definition), non-empty, and open, which implies that XXX is disconnected, a contradiction.

Path-Connectedness

Definition

Let (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) be a metric space. Then XXX is path-connected if for any two points x,y∈Xx, y \in Xx,y∈X, there exists a continuous function γ ⁣:[0,1]→X\func{\gamma}{\br{0,1}}{X}γ:[0,1]→X such that γ(0)=x\gamma\p{0} = xγ(0)=x and γ(1)=y\gamma\p{1} = yγ(1)=y.
Remark.

In your homework, you will prove that path-connected   ⟹  \implies⟹ connected. However, the converse is not true in general, i.e., there are connected metric spaces which are not path-connected.

Sometimes, it's easier to show that a metric space is path-connected than it is to show that it's connected directly.

Example 4.

Show that

E={f∈C([0,1]) | f(0)=0}E = \set{f \in C\p{\br{0,1}} \st f\p{0} = 0}E={f∈C([0,1])∣f(0)=0}

is a connected subset of C([0,1])C\p{\br{0, 1}}C([0,1]) with the sup⁡\supsup-metric.
Solution.

We'll show that EEE is path-connected. Let f,g∈Ef, g \in Ef,g∈E, and define the line segment (or homotopy) between them via γ ⁣:[0,1]→E\func{\gamma}{\br{0,1}}{E}γ:[0,1]→E,

γt(x)=(1−t)f(x)+tg(x).\gamma_t\p{x} = \p{1 - t}f\p{x} + tg\p{x}.γt​(x)=(1−t)f(x)+tg(x).

For any t∈[0,1]t \in \br{0, 1}t∈[0,1], the function γt(x)\gamma_t\p{x}γt​(x) is continuous since it's a linear combination of the continuous functions fff and ggg, and

γt(0)=(1−t)f(0)+tg(0)=0,\gamma_t\p{0} = \p{1 - t}f\p{0} + tg\p{0} = 0,γt​(0)=(1−t)f(0)+tg(0)=0,

so γ\gammaγ is well-defined (i.e., it actually gives me functions in EEE).

If f=gf = gf=g, then γ\gammaγ is constant in ttt, so it's automatically continuous. If f≠gf \neq gf=g, then let ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0.

∣γt(x)−γs(x)∣=∣(1−t)f(x)+tg(x)−((1−s)f(x)+sg(x))∣=∣(s−t)f(x)+(t−s)g(x)∣=∣(t−s)(g(x)−f(x))∣≤∣s−t∣sup⁡z∈[0,1]∣f(z)−g(z)∣⏟≕ Cf,g  ⟹  sup⁡x∈[0,1]∣γt(x)−γs(x)∣≤Cf,g∣t−s∣.\begin{aligned} \abs{\gamma_t\p{x} - \gamma_s\p{x}} &= \abs{\p{1 - t}f\p{x} + tg\p{x} - \p{\p{1 - s}f\p{x} + sg\p{x}}} \\ &= \abs{\p{s - t}f\p{x} + \p{t - s}g\p{x}} \\ &= \abs{\p{t - s}\p{g\p{x} - f\p{x}}} \\ &\leq \abs{s - t} \underbrace{\sup_{z \in \br{0, 1}}{\abs{f\p{z} - g\p{z}}}}_{\eqqcolon\:C_{f,g}} \\ \implies \sup_{x \in \br{0, 1}}{\abs{\gamma_t\p{x} - \gamma_s\p{x}}} \\ &\leq C_{f,g}\abs{t - s}. \end{aligned}∣γt​(x)−γs​(x)∣⟹x∈[0,1]sup​∣γt​(x)−γs​(x)∣​=∣(1−t)f(x)+tg(x)−((1−s)f(x)+sg(x))∣=∣(s−t)f(x)+(t−s)g(x)∣=∣(t−s)(g(x)−f(x))∣≤∣s−t∣=:Cf,g​z∈[0,1]sup​∣f(z)−g(z)∣​​≤Cf,g​∣t−s∣.​

Cf,gC_{f,g}Cf,g​ exists and is finite because ∣f−g∣\abs{f - g}∣f−g∣ is a continuous function on the compact set [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1]. Moreover, Cf,g≠0C_{f,g} \neq 0Cf,g​=0 since we assumed that f≠gf \neq gf=g. Thus, we can pick δ=εCf,g\delta = \frac{\epsilon}{C_{f,g}}δ=Cf,g​ε​. Then if ∣t−s∣<δ\abs{t - s} < \delta∣t−s∣<δ, we get

d(γt,γs)=sup⁡x∈[0,1]∣γt(x)−γs(x)∣≤Cf,g∣t−s∣<Cf,g⋅εCf,g=ε,\begin{aligned} d\p{\gamma_t, \gamma_s} &= \sup_{x \in \br{0, 1}}{\abs{\gamma_t\p{x} - \gamma_s\p{x}}} \\ &\leq C_{f,g}\abs{t - s} \\ &< C_{f,g} \cdot \frac{\epsilon}{C_{f,g}} \\ &= \epsilon, \end{aligned}d(γt​,γs​)​=x∈[0,1]sup​∣γt​(x)−γs​(x)∣≤Cf,g​∣t−s∣<Cf,g​⋅Cf,g​ε​=ε,​

so γ\gammaγ is continuous in ttt. In other words, γ\gammaγ is a valid path between fff and ggg, so EEE is path-connected, hence connected.

Connectedness and Continuity

Proposition

If f ⁣:(X,dX)→(Y,dY)\func{f}{\p{X, d_X}}{\p{Y, d_Y}}f:(X,dX​)→(Y,dY​) is continuous and E⊆XE \subseteq XE⊆X is connected, then f(E)⊆Yf\p{E} \subseteq Yf(E)⊆Y is connected.

Like with compact sets, we say "the continuous image of a connected set is connected."

This can be a useful way to show that some sets are connected directly.

Example 5.

Let f ⁣:R→R\func{f}{\R}{\R}f:R→R be a continuous function. Show that its graph

Γ={(x,f(x)) | x∈R}\Gamma = \set{\p{x, f\p{x}} \st x \in \R}Γ={(x,f(x))∣x∈R}

is a connected subset of R2\R^2R2.
Solution.

We can define F ⁣:R→Γ\func{F}{\R}{\Gamma}F:R→Γ by F(x)=(x,f(x))F\p{x} = \p{x, f\p{x}}F(x)=(x,f(x)). By construction, Γ=F(R)\Gamma = F\p{\R}Γ=F(R), and since R\RR is connected, if we show that FFF is continuous, we automatically know that Γ\GammaΓ is connected.

Let ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0 and fix x0∈Rx_0 \in \Rx0​∈R. Recall that

dℓ2(F(x),F(x0))=(x−x0)2+(f(x)−f(x0))2.d_{\ell^2}\p{F\p{x}, F\p{x_0}} = \sqrt{\p{x - x_0}^2 + \p{f\p{x} - f\p{x_0}}^2}.dℓ2​(F(x),F(x0​))=(x−x0​)2+(f(x)−f(x0​))2​.

Since fff is continuous, there exists δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 such that if ∣x−y∣<δ\abs{x - y} < \delta∣x−y∣<δ, then ∣f(x)−f(y)∣<ε2\abs{f\p{x} - f\p{y}} < \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt{2}}∣f(x)−f(y)∣<2​ε​. Thus, if ∣x−y∣<min⁡{δ,ε2}\abs{x - y} < \min\set{\delta, \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt{2}}}∣x−y∣<min{δ,2​ε​}, then

∣x−x0∣<ε2and∣f(x)−f(x0)∣<ε2,\abs{x - x_0} < \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt{2}} \quad\text{and}\quad \abs{f\p{x} - f\p{x_0}} < \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt{2}},∣x−x0​∣<2​ε​and∣f(x)−f(x0​)∣<2​ε​,

so

dℓ2(F(x),F(x0))<ε22+ε22=ε,d_{\ell^2}\p{F\p{x}, F\p{x_0}} < \sqrt{\frac{\epsilon^2}{2} + \frac{\epsilon^2}{2}} = \epsilon,dℓ2​(F(x),F(x0​))<2ε2​+2ε2​​=ε,

so FFF is continuous, which means Γ\GammaΓ is connected.
